Unstoppable
Untargetable
Wet
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Status.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Stunned
item.description: A more extreme form of being Dazed. Creature cannot take any actions or movement. Creature is Surprised.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stunned.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Submerged
item.description: Target is completely surrounded in liquid. This triggers Aquatic Combat and Improved Cover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Submerged.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Surprised
item.description:
Creature is unable to respond effectively to attacks due to Stealth, Feinting, or some other status or Circumstance. Attacks made against a Surprised creature get a +10 bonus.
This status effect is also a Circumstance that can be determined on a per-creature or per-attack basis, but can also be a condition that applies to all incoming attacks.
Creatures Surprised by the start of a combat also place below non-Surprised creatures regardless of Initiative result.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Surprised.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Taunted
item.description:
A Taunted creature must use all their attacks on the target of the taunt, and must include the target in all of their special attacks (Spells, SU, etc.). A taunted creature can only move if the movement puts them closer to the creature that taunted it.
A creature taunted by 2 or more creatures may decide which they'd like to attack (assuming they attack at all).
More extreme forms of taunt may restrict the types of actions the creature can take while taunted.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Taunted.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Time Out
item.description:
A creature in Time Out has lost the will to fight, and has surrendered to you. They cannot inflict harmful effects on anybody or anything. They also cannot cast spells without your permission. They meekly follow your commands (ex. follow me), but won’t do anything against their ethos (kick that puppy) or that is dangerous (jump off that cliff) without extreme circumstances. If you or your allies attack the creature or cast a harmful spell on it, the condition ends.
Treat it like a slightly more convenient form of unconsciousness if you want to interact with the creature after the combat. Many minion type creatures will acquire this status effect when their leader is defeated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Time Out.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Unassailable
item.description: Creature ignores penalties that result from Circumstance or Status.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Unassailable.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Unstoppable
item.description: Creature cannot be moved by force, and can move and take actions normally regardless of any status.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Unstoppable.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Untargetable
item.description: Creature cannot be targeted.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Untargetable.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Wet
item.description:
Gain weakness to Electric and Cold Damage. When a wet creature takes Electric or Cold damage, the condition ends.
Being wet is something that can come up often in the environment. Only by being drenched in heavy rain, submerged in water or something similar can one be considered wet to the point where this has a mechanical effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Wet.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Abnegation
item.description: These spells focus on disabling magic and protection.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Abnegation.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Conjuration
item.description: These spells focus on summoning, displacement, and temporary creation.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Conjuration.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Divination
item.description: These spells focus on gaining knowledge through spying and querying the universe.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Divination.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Evocation
item.description: These spells focus on the manipulating elements and focusing power to destructive effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Evocation.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Illusion
item.description:
These spells focus on warping perception to impose one's will over others.
Enchantment spells are Illusion spells that are also Mind-Affecting.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Illusion.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Transmutation
item.description: These spells focus on changing things into other things.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Transmutation.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Air
item.description:
Effect manipulates air to produce its effect.
This is a non-Damage elemental tag.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Bond
item.description: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Buff
item.description: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Caloric
item.description: Effect either creates Food, or has special interactions when using it.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Charm
item.description: Charm effects allow the creature inflicting it to exert some degree of control over others. All charm effects are also Mind-Affecting.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Companion
item.description:
In media it's very common for creatures to have minions, squires and sidekicks. This is what the companion system is for. Like most other content, the companion system is ill-suited for large quantities of creatures, like armies. It's meant to be more compact. Something to take with you on the go for your adventure. This could also reasonably extend to temporary allies that join your party.
Companions are generally tied to your class, abilities and items. Any such ability is marked with this tag.
If an ability has the companion tag, it summons an ally, or otherwise serves some kind of interpersonal function.
You can only have 2 companions, or 1 if you have -1 CHA.
Companions always act on your turn if you are present. There is no separation between your turns, you all act in the same Initiative (rolled by you).
Companions gain bonuses or penalties based off of your CHA.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Concentration
item.description:
An effect with the Concentration tag requires some degree of upkeep from the caster and typically has a duration. Concentration effects end if the caster is Defeated, Stunned, put Asleep, or otherwise completely prevented from taking any actions. You can also cease concentration Instantly.
If you cast a spell with concentration, you must hold the staff in order to maintain your concentration. Being disarmed of a staff you are using to concentrate ends the effect. While you are concentrating on a spell, you cannot use that staff to cast other spells. However, you can use another staff to cast spells, or concentrate on another.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Contingent
item.description:
The effect can be cast ahead of time with a specific trigger for when it activates. A creature can only have a single contingent effect active on them at once.
The effect manifests as a clearly visible wisp of energy that floats around the creature. The DC to identify the effect increases by 5, but the fact that there is a contingent effect is clear.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Curse
item.description: Curse effects inflict permanent debilitating conditions on creatures. Curses cannot be dispelled, but they all have some way to get rid of them. This usually requires some convoluted action most people wouldn't do unless prompted. Can be identified using the "identify curse or affliction" feature in the Medicine skill.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: D
item.description:
Dismissible (D) effects can be ended prematurely by the caster as a Standard Action.
Note that voluntary effects (such as buffs) can be dismissed Instantly without this tag.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Damage
item.description:
Damage is a value that subtracts from a target's HP when the effect takes place.
"Losing HP" is synonymous with taking Damage.
Damage is always assigned a type. The physical damage types are Crush, Slash, and Pierce, and the elemental types are Magic, Lightning, Fire, Cold, Holy, Poison, and Psychic. These are also Tags.
For Weapons, this value is determined by the weapon used and adds your STR. A Technique may add to this as well.
For Spells, this value is determined by your LV and SP.
Any given effect will describe how to determine the damage it deals.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Darkness
item.description: Effect either creates darkness, or has special interactions when in it.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Earth
item.description:
Spell manipulates earth to produce its effect.
This is a non-Damage elemental tag.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Elusive
item.description: Elusive: This action doesn't provoke an AoO.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Fear
item.description: Usually inflicts Shaken or Frightened. All fear effects are also Mind-Affecting.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Figment
item.description:
Figments create creatures, objects, and terrain that don’t truly exist. As long as the creature does not directly interact with a figment, it believes it to be real. If a creature figures out that it's fake and tells its allies, or demonstrates by moving through it, they no longer believe it to be real. Directly interacting requires doing things like walking into a wall or attacking a creature, upon which the creature rolls a Will save. A failure indicates the creature will try to run around an obstacle or that they missed a creature.
If used to satisfy the conditions of a surrender (such as making a spooky monster), the creatures affected get a will save to negate it. They have +6 on this save if they saw you cast the spell.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Glamer
item.description: A Glamer changes a subject’s sensory qualities, making it look, feel, taste, smell, or sound like something else, or nothing at all.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Language
item.description: Language effects require the target to understand your spoken words, or requires some form of clear communication that mimics language (like Telepathy).
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Light
item.description: Effect either creates light, or has special interactions when in it.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Martial
item.description:
Martial effects allow the user to deliver the effect using the ACC and Damage and On-Hit Effects of a wielded Weapon, even if it mentions using another form of attack.
Martial techniques and Special Attacks by default ALWAYS have the martial tag. It is not listed to save time/space.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Mind-Affecting
item.description: Mind-Affecting effects are a more general group that include things like Fear effects, Charms, and more. Creatures that are Mindless cannot be affected by mind-affecting effects.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Multi-Strike
item.description: This effect, when used with an Action-Attack, is improved by attacking multiple times. It may apply its effect to every attack on your turn.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Pattern
item.description: Like a Figment, a Pattern creates an image that others can see, but a pattern also affects the minds of those who see it or are caught in it. Common effects include Fascination or Blurred Vision. Pattern effects are also Mind-Affecting.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Persistent
item.description: Persistent Effects have an initial effect and an effect that persists over time. This type of effect cannot deal its persistent effect on the same round as its initial effect. Persistent effects end preemptively if the user is Defeated.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Polymorph
item.description:
Polymorph effects transform creatures into other creatures. Many of the features granted from polymorph effects are based off the Shapeshifter's class features. You retain the ability to speak while polymorphed. When transforming using a polymorph effect, it can fall under one of the following to determine the nature of your transformation (some can be multiple).
Chimeric Polymorph - Your form stays roughly the same, but acquires some features of the new creature that you're transforming into, such as claws, fur, a long tongue etc. When you chimeric polymorph, you do not lose access to any of your gear.
True Polymorph - Your form completely changes to the form mentioned in the ability. You completely lose access to all of your equipment. There are only a handful of features recognizable from your previous self, such as eye color.
Baleful Polymorph - This form of polymorph is inflicted upon you rather than willingly used. It functions very similarly to true polymorph, but provides fewer tangible benefits and often include debilitating Status. You lose access to your equipment and cannot speak.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Scrying
item.description:
Scrying effects create a specific type of magic sensor, often from remote locations, usually for the purpose of spying on people. The sensor allows you to see and hear anything with any of your senses, so long as it is in the specified range the effect mentions.
Scrying sensors are clearly visible to the naked eye. They usually take the form of an eye. Sensors that can move can use the caster's stealth bonus to hide as they move.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Sigil
item.description: The effect puts magical text on a surface with some kind of delayed effect, usually triggering when a creature walks within a certain radius of the sigil. A sigil must be clearly visible in order to function. If it is obscured, then it is deactivated until it is unobscured. Most sigils have the ability to apply a passphrase that, when spoken aloud, allows a user to move through the area without triggering the sigil.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Subtle
item.description: The effect has a chance for nobody to notice it. If the target creature fails its save, then the effect goes unnoticed. The DC to identify a spell with the subtle tag increases by 5.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Tags
item.description:
Tags are descriptors that let you apply general rules to similar effects. Tags are not just limited to spells, but spells do commonly use tags. Certain tags may only effect specific parts of an ability. Use discretion when needed.

item.title: Teleportation
item.description: Teleportation effects allow the user, and sometimes their allies, to instantly travel between two locations. Teleportation tends to be very limited in scope, bringing you to very specific predetermined places or being wildly off-course if not. If unspecified, you must have line of sight to the location you are teleporting to.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Water
item.description:
Effect manipulates water to produce its effect.
This is a non-Damage elemental tag.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Rolling Dice and Statistics
item.description:
This game relies on a special roll, detailed below. It will be referred to as dX in the content.
Action resolution is done by using random chance to represent a range of success in an attempt to reach a target number, combined with a bonus based on your character's build, such as from their ability scores, skills, class features, active buffs, and feats.
Content is currently being made with a roll equivalent to counting successes on a d15 die, exploding on any number above 1, success being any roll (including the first). This can be written into rolling simulator websites such as Roll20 to speed things up.
The benefit of this method is that anyone can roll any number, unlike other systems where a large enough target number will make the roll impossible.
The Short Version: Every point added for or against these rolls is about a 7% difference in power. This means Attack Rolls, Skill checks, Saving Throws, DCs, Avoid, all of it. A 6 point difference is roughly a 50% boost in odds. A 10 point difference is about double. As an example, if you gain 10 Accuracy or 10 Stealth, your odds of success are about twice as high. This is the case regardless of the opponent's statistics.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Rolling Dice and Statistics.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Armor
item.description:
Armors of varying weights have STR requirements, granting more AC at higher values. You lose 10 Speed and Jump for every point of STR you lack (minimum 5). Armor takes the Armor Equipment Slot.
The following are the three most simple and common forms of armor. Light armor consists of hard leathers and gambesons, medium armor includes chain and scales with breastplates, and heavy armor covers every part of the body with a combination of plate, chain, and gambesons.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Shield
item.description:
Shields are a subtype Weapon Group. Not all shields can be used as weapons, however.
Shields are primarily used to gain defensive abilities to use as Actions, and most also passively increase your defenses (Mainly AC). Many shields have minimum STR requirements just like Armor, which penalize you in the same manner.
Unless otherwise stated, shields are 1-handed.
The following are the basic shields.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Background
item.description:
Background helps to determine what your character was doing before they got sucked up into an adventure. Other than acquiring the skills necessary to go out into the dangerous world, of course.
Backgrounds give starting bonuses or equipment.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Family Man
item.description:
You are the primary owner of a house somewhere in the world, usually at least on the tangent of civilization. You lived with either your immediate family, like parents and siblings, or you made a family of your own with a spouse and children.
You own a meager house in a specific place, and a handful of family members to come home to after an adventure. Your house is always considered a suitable place to rest in order to cure general afflictions.
See Backgrounds
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Noble
item.description:
You come from an upper ring of society. Your name might not carry the same weight everywhere you go, but your gold pouch certainly does.
You get a bonus 1,000 starting gold that you can spend as you wish. Your family also gives you an allowance every month of 500g. For campaigns with a faster or slower pace, such as if there are frequent time skips, consider changing how often the allowance comes in.
If you are far from home, it can take up to a week for your allowance to arrive. They can only ever be picked up from settlements.
See Backgrounds
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Tradesman
item.description:
You worked in a job that required a specialized form of training, such as an alchemist, a doctor or a blacksmith. Over the years of your work you have accumulated a few tools of the trade.
Select one of the following presets, or make one that's similar. Regardless of the selected trade, you have a place of work that you can return to that views you favorably, has masterwork equipment available for use, and that you can get +10% Wealth from through related sales and deals.
Doctor - You start off with a medicine kit, a dose of troll oil, and 3 doses of Bloodblock.
Alchemist - Start off with an alchemist kit, a love potion, and 2 alchemist fires.
Craftsman (weapons/armor) - Start off with a set of combat ready equipment. You can start off with

Heavy armor and a weapon
Medium armor, 3 melee weapons, a ranged weapon, and a shield
Light armor, 6 light melee weapons, 2 ranged weapons, and a shield
See Backgrounds
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Wanderer
item.description:
You go wherever the road takes you. You might have had a home once, but for one reason or another you had to or wanted to leave.
You start play with a standard rock. More information can be found in the bestiary. Very basically, rocks are autonomous mass transportation and shipping vehicles. Most significant places in civilization will have service stations and parking available.
See Backgrounds
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Common Prices
item.description:
LV 1 Characters start off with 3000g to spend. Higher level characters should get more gold, determined by the DM and as appropriate for the sort of campaign being run.
The following are prices of basic equipment. Recall that basic equipment is the lowest quality available. This is budget equipment suitable for militias, thugs, and beginner adventurers.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Economics
item.description:
Daily income, typically through the use of a skill, like profession, perform or alchemy.
All income is based around a formula which calculates a yearly salary (y) based on your skill bonus (x).
y=10000+x^2 * 250
Salary assumes you work for 5 days a week, 50 weeks a year. Divide this value by 250 to figure our your daily income. The chart below does this formula for you for most expected values. Anything lower than a +0 bonus to the task at hand makes a 5k salary, or 20g daily.
This formula assumes a prosperous nation with a lot of economic opportunity and a population with many thousands of people per city. In poorer and less populous regions, consider using the following multiplier for all goods and services.
Developing - Multiply all values by .75
Poor - Multiply all values by .5
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: The Cost of Living
item.description:
Staying alive requires resources and food. The easiest way to obtain and represent these is to spend money. Only accounting for minimum food and necessities, the basic cost to remaining alive is 10g per day.
In a town, where sleeping on the streets isn't advised, the cost increases to 30g.
The savings from living in the wilderness are made up by the time spent setting up camps and creating one's own resources, as per Live off Land. Characters that do not spend this money must spend additional time collecting enough food to survive. Players should lose this much gold every day to represent the use of supplies. If they are on a particularly long journey where they will not encounter others to sell them supplies, they must spend this money ahead of time to avoid running out of supplies.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: The Value of Gold
item.description:
Estimating the true value of a single unit of currency is difficult to do when considering the possibilities of every setting. However, in order to establish some reference for pricing adventuring gear and items, we have to settle on one - so, for the purposes of the default pricing and earnings, we're going forward with the assumption that the differences between the peasants, tradesmen, and aristocrats is large, but not in such a way that compromises the ability of the peasantry to afford basic items.
As a fantasy setting with swords and monsters, there are comparisons to be made to the value of labor in the medieval era. However, in order to avoid mixing the complexities of medieval economics with magic and superheroes to an audience that may not have studied such, the gap between the peasants and aristocrats is reduced, and social mobility is substantially increased.
If a more extreme economy is desired, adjust the earnings from Economics and The Cost of Living.
Average laborers like farmers can be expected to make ~10-20k gold every year, with the amount increasing with more sophisticated trades such as smiths or merchants.
Gold pieces are small coins and are virtually weightless due to the minting process performed by the financial wizards. Another benefit of this minting is that it causes gold pieces to naturally stack into specific values (5, 10, 20, 100, 1000). Someone can easily hold 100g in their pockets, or 1000g in a dedicated pouch. Anything more and they are bursting at the seams and would be better off with a bank, or to switch to alternative methods of payment.
Carrying around a bag of 100,000g would be like the real-world equivalent of carrying around a several briefcases full of paper currency. While this may happen for large transactions or when hauling away a dragon's horde, it's usually difficult to avoid drawing attention if you were to do it on the regular.
When imagining gold costs, use the following:
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Food
item.description:
Food is one of the most common and necessary consumable resources to survive difficult journeys and dangerous dungeons. It is the slower, more efficient alternative to potions, which may grant their benefits briefly or in smaller amounts at a moment's notice.
It is assumed all food items are portioned properly as a meal, and cooked to preserve. They never spoil as long as they are in a container and are not damaged directly, such as by fire. Raw ingredients will spoil unless cooked.
Food is consumed during a Short Rest over 15 minutes, unless otherwise stated.
Food primarily restores HP, but may grant bonus effects until you eat again or Long Rest.
The value of a particular food increases with how much it heals/what it grants and how little it weighs.
The creation of food requires edible organic materials, time, and skill. See Cooking for more.
The following are some basic examples of food:
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Mundane Item
item.description: Mundane Items can usually be bought in many locations around the world with the correct vendor in town. Many have real life analogues.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Property
item.description:
Mundane Item.
Property is synonymous with land, and everything on it. Property can include facilities, homes, or resources of interest. The price of property changes based on a few factors, such as size, buildings, appearance, location, and the overall state its in, to name a few.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Tools
item.description:
80g Mundane Item
Tools typically come in sets catered to a specific task, such as fishing or medicine. Some tasks require the use of tools, others only give a penalty if you don't have tools.
Tools also come in a masterwork variety, giving the user a +4 bonus on the skill in question. The price is increased to 800g.
Some tasks do not have associated tools, and therefore are not suitable for acquiring masterwork variants to them. Skills like medicine, alchemy and profession use tools. Skills like stealth, perception and persuasion do not. Some types of tools might be able to aid you with novel types of tasks, such as using a spyglass to roll perception long distances, but should not give any types of persistent flat bonuses.
Most tool kits weigh 10 lbs. Some tasks, such as smithing, require even more advanced tools you can't carry around, such as a forge.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Torch
item.description:
10g Mundane Item
Torches are sticks wrapped with some type of cloth, chemical or vegetable matter that is flammable. Torches give off bright light in a 20 ft radius around them, and dim light 20 ft past that.
They can stay lit for up to 2 hours. Lighting and dimming a torch repeatedly can significantly decrease the amount of time they stay lit.
If a torch ends up getting wet, it becomes unusable.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Ammunition
item.description:
Ammunition is a subtype Weapon Group. All Ammunition is either also part of another Weapon Group, or does not function as a weapon on its own.
These represent arrows, bolts, rocks, bullets, darts, or any other weapon that is either part of another weapon's use, or that is meant to be launched by itself in quick succession.
Ammunition can be drawn as an Instant Action.
Ammunition and its price and weight represent an unlimited source. You cannot easily "share" or otherwise split Ammunition between allies. You either have the ammunition or you don't - Exceptions can be made in the heat of combat, such as firing back an arrow that just hit a tree next to you.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Ammunition.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Natural Weapon
item.description:
Natural Weapons are a subtype Weapon Group. All Natural Weapons are also part of another Weapon Group.
These weapons are part of a creature's being. Examples include claws, fists, tails, horns, stingers, and tentacles.
Most natural weapons are not universal, meaning they are different for each creature that has them and will be noted as such in their stat block. However, they do follow common trends.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Natural Weapon.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Staff
item.description:
Staves are a subtype Weapon Group. This is also a label used for anything that can complete the Staff component of spells.
Not all items that can complete the Staff component of spells are weapons.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Staff.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Axe
item.description:
Axes are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed.
These weapons are made to cut or pierce using chopping motions.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Axe group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Axe.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Blade
item.description:
Blades are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed.
These weapons are meant for slicing and stabbing, relying on the blade to do the cutting with a mere touch rather than chopping or committed thrusts.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Blade group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Blade.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Bludgeon
item.description:
Bludgeons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed.
These weapons are meant to beat the snot out of enemies in the most primitive way possible.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Bludgeon group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Bludgeon.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Bow
item.description:
Bows are a group of Weapons that are 2-handed.
These are curved weapons held at the ends by taut or resistant elastic strings used for firing Ammunition with a drawing motion.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Bow group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Bow.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Close
item.description:
Close Weapons are a group of Weapons that are "1-handed".
These represent punches, kicks, claws, and headbutts that can be used in the closest of combat, even when pinned. These attacks can be with one's own Natural Weapons, or with weapons augmenting their limbs.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Close group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Close.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Dagger
item.description:
Daggers are a group of Weapons that are 1-handed.
These are short, sharp weapons for getting close to enemies and striking weak spots or overwhelming them with angles of attack.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Dagger group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Dagger.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Polearm
item.description:
Polearms are a group of Weapons that are 2-handed.
These are long skirmish weapons for battlefield versatility. They combine the spacing of spears with the swings of axes. Often used to hook enemies in addition to being general weapons.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Polearm group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Polearm.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Thrown
item.description:
Thrown weapons are a group of Weapons that are almost always 1-handed.
These are weapons designed to be thrown using a swing from the hand or sling. Casters are armored gauntlets with thrown ammunition stored inside, used to draw and throw faster and harder. Many Thrown weapons are also Ammunition.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Thrown group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Thrown.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Thrust
item.description:
Thrust weapons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed.
These are blades and spears meant for dedicated thrusts to put enormous pressure at a single point. Often used to outrange and lunge at opponents.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Thrust group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Thrust.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Trigger
item.description:
Trigger weapons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed.
These are weapons with handles that are loaded beforehand and then fire their ammunition with a trigger.
Trigger weapons require an Action-Attack to reload.
Trigger weapons do not add STR to damage.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Trigger group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Trigger.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Basic Weapon
item.description: Basic Weapons are the default Weapons of a Weapon Group. They represent the effectiveness of common or makeshift weaponry. They have no Upgrade Slots, and come with the fewest amount of Weapon Qualities.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Exotic Weapon
item.description: Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into any Weapon Groups, and will list how they differ. They often break the norms of conventional weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Range
item.description: Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range being the accurate range, and the Y taking a -4 penalty.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Special Attack
item.description:
Special Attacks are qualities that a Weapon can have that temporarily grant you a Technique as long as you wield them. You must use the weapon when performing the Special Attack. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Technique unless otherwise stated.
Special Attacks uses are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer. This means you can't take the Recharge action and then pass it off to another creature to use their own Recharge.
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Weapon
item.description:
Weapons are the most basic method of increasing one's offensive power. Just having a weapon and attacking an enemy is often enough to make you a substantial threat, regardless of your expertise or abilities.
Weapons fall into Weapon Groups for the purpose of identifying what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it.
There are ten main categories:

And 4 subtypes:

Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into these categories, and will list how they differ.
Weapons come with damage values, attack speed values, and damage types as their core stats, in addition to the categories listed above.
All standard weapons deal a physical Damage type. If a weapon has more than one damage type, you can decide which to use before you make a given attack with it.
Damage values and Attack Speed correlate such that the damage tends to be very similar without any additional abilities or STR. The typical offense-oriented damage values and AS are as follows:

Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range being the accurate range, and the Y taking a -4 penalty, referred to as the Range.

Some weapons come with Techniques and Special Attacks. These temporarily grant you a technique as long as you wield them. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Technique unless otherwise stated.
Special Attacks specifically are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer.

item.title: Weapon Group
item.description:
A Weapon Group is a categorization of Weapons that describes the way it is used in combat, and is used to identify what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it.
There are 10 main groups: Axe, Blade, Bludgeon, Bow, Close, Dagger, Polearm, Thrown/Caster, Thrust, and Trigger,
and 4 sub-groups: Ammunition, Natural, Shield, and Staff.

item.title: Difficulty and Integrity
item.description:
The Equivocation of Optional Mechanics as Difficulty Management in Video Games

In the ongoing conversation about difficulty in games, it is crucial to recognize the different ways designers shape challenge—whether through numeric adjustments, increased enemy complexity, or opt-in mechanics like summoning or assistive features. Unfortunately, many argue that all optional mechanics are neutral tools for difficulty management that do not impact the core gameplay experience. As players and developers, we should focus on creating environments that allow individuals to experience the game in the way they prefer—including doing so without imposing significant changes that undermine the integrity of the core challenge. The goal should be to empower players while respecting both the game’s design and their personal approach to difficulty.

In the gaming landscape, the design of difficulty and balance is a necessary part of accessibility for users with handicaps - especially in harder titles. Players that are too old or too new, that have responsibilities that pull them from the game, limited time, or that simply lack the necessary abilities to enjoy a game should have the necessary means to level the playing field.
The design of difficulty in games can be broadly categorized into three distinct approaches: numeric, complexity-based, and opt-in mechanics.

Numeric difficulty involves straightforward adjustments such as increasing enemy health, damage output, or resource scarcity, making encounters more difficult through quantifiable means. This is the most simple approach, and is used as part of the other approaches - but alone is often only appropriate for games with minimalist mechanics and low skill expression.
Complexity-based difficulty, on the other hand, will change enemies to act with more intelligence, have more varied abilities and attack patterns, and require players to master the mechanics already present in the game to keep up. This is often the preferred method for any game with strategy or skill expression, but is the most taxing to implement.
Finally, opt-in mechanics—such as summoning allies, flying, or activating other assistive features—allow players to choose whether to bypass or mitigate certain challenges altogether. While these mechanics are often presented as optional tools for difficulty management, their adoption and integration can fundamentally alter the player’s experience.
There's a clear outlier here. There are no limits to what developers can put into their games as "optional" mechanics. The flexibility is a double-edged sword, as the implementation can just as easily ruin the experience if there is not an appropriate alternative or less invasive means.
For the purposes of this discussion, I will mainly refer to Skyrim, Mario, and Elden Ring.

All three methods of designing difficulty can easily interrupt the core gameplay experience when implemented thoughtlessly.
In Skyrim, there is very little strategy and skill expression. At best, the player can move out of the range of some enemy attacks and strike back between them, or properly aim an arrow. Beyond that, the game is no different to MMOs such as RuneScape, where the player either engages in a slap fight whose winner is determined entirely by opposing statistics and how much healing is in their inventories, or the player stands out of reach of a melee opponent and attacks them with ranged weapons until they die helplessly.
Skyrim uses numeric difficulty. Despite being the easiest approach, there are major oversights in its implementation that force players to use specific playstyles or exploits to keep up. For example, a player that wants to use primarily destruction magic will be greatly disappointed on higher difficulties as their entire Magicka bar is depleted defeating a single lesser bandit, and the abysmal regeneration rate and lack of potions will force them to resort to sword fighting or the use of AI exploits and loading zones. As the game progresses, the only way to have enough Magicka to defeat enemies without hours of grinding is through Alchemy-Enchanting exploits that bring the cost of spells to 0, or their damage to arbitrarily high numbers—the latter of which completely defeats the purpose of the numeric difficulty increase.
Complexity-based difficulty is the hardest to implement. With the exception of complexity through AI improvements, it requires making more content on top of what should already be an adequate amount of content for lower difficulties. The more mechanics an enemy has, the higher the odds that they will invalidate a certain method of playing the game and require players to do something they are not interested in. For example, if the difficulty is in higher enemy aggression, then any playstyle that relies on large openings is going to suffer disproportionately. If the difficulty is in close-range incapacitation, then melee players will suffer more than ranged ones. Sacrificing some part of the original experience is often inevitable.
There are exceptions where the numeric and complexity approaches meet. The speed of a game and the precision of its timings are a good example—Most of the game remains untouched, and a small adjustment in the reaction time necessary to beat the game can be the difficulty a player wants.
At the crux of the issue lies difficulty through optional mechanics. These are the most likely to change the experience of a player.
In Elden Ring, the variety of abilities in the game ranges from completely impractical to game-trivializing superpowers. Some are very similar to each other, such as two weapons of the same class with similar movesets that have wildly different performance. Most are not at all similar, making the experience when switching from one to the next completely different. Despite this, one could make an argument that the difficulty in the game rises from which strategies the player chooses.
The most polarizing optional mechanic is Summoning. This changes the game from single player to Co-Op vs AI, or Co-Op and AI vs AI. Using this, a player can use NPC assistants to make enemies ignore the player, or simply ask a friend to beat the game for them while they watch. The extreme nature of this mechanic has caused heated debate in online communities as to what extent an optional mechanic can be used to manage difficulty before it simply becomes thinly veiled cheating.

Cheating in most games is simply breaking the rules to your benefit. In the context of early video games, cheating was specifically programmed into games using "cheat codes" that would allow players to break the rules. Later, specialized pieces of hardware such as Action Replay were introduced that are akin to modern hex editors, allowing players to cheat by changing any variable they could find, far beyond what developers willingly included in their games. All of these were widely agreed to be forms of cheating.
And yet, the definition of cheating became more flexible as time passed, even though little changed in what players were capable of.
In Super Mario games, there exist powerups that grant the player complete invincibility combined with another powerup that only appear when a player has died in a level multiple times. These are essentially easily accessible god modes that can be used to skip content that is too difficult or boring to play normally, or for any other reason the players see fit.
There is no code that needs to be input. There is no need to go out of one's way to obtain these powerups. They aren't even labeled as cheats. They are even included with explicit intent to be used by a portion of the player base—while many cheats in the past were added just for the sake of having cheats (such as with Big Head Mode) or as rewards for completing the game.
And yet, despite the lack of labeling, there is a subtle acknowledgement that using these is different than beating the game "normally." Achievements and collectibles will look different, scores may be altered, and the game otherwise records your use of these items to give your completion of the game an asterisk.
The difference between invincibility powerups and other cheats is that invincibility powerups are deliberate additions intended to help players of lower skill or patience complete the game. They are easy, low-effort inclusions that sacrifice a portion of the gameplay for an easier experience, which would sour the experience for players that do not need them. They are still, however, cheats. They break the rules to your benefit.
In Skyrim (PC), the player can, at any time, open the console to manipulate the game via console commands. This is more akin to classic cheat codes, where no player would be able to guess what they need to type into the console to cause a specific effect without looking up the codes, but is closer to the power of hex editors in terms of possibilities.
Skyrim's console blurs the concept of cheating far more than a handicap feature would. Unlike other cheat codes, the use of the console is far more common even among players that do not like cheats for one reason: Skyrim does not function as a game.
Did the player get stuck in random map geometry? The console allows them to teleport out. Did a quest break? The console can skip to the next step. Did the game crash? The console can be used to restore progress without needing to replay content.
By definition, these are all instances of cheating, yet many would decline to call it such. Cheating has a harsh connotation that someone is cheapening an experience by breaking the rules, and yet this time the cheats are used specifically to improve the experience of a broken game—and arguably play closer to the rules as intended.

How do you know what a developer's intentions are? Intuition is a helpful tool, but it is also often wrong. Unless someone spoke their intentions, there cannot be certainty... But we can still make reasonably educated guesses.
In Elden Ring, a common argument in favor of using anything the game offers is that, if it's in the game, it's intended to be used. The developers wouldn't have added it if they didn't intend for players to use it. This is obviously a baseless assertion, and there are plenty of examples where this intuitive reasoning falls short.
Soon after the game's release, there were debates as to whether or not weapons such as Rivers of Blood and summons such as Mimic Tear were so powerful as to be unintended, or even be considered cheating. Players that defended these inclusions used the above argument, only to later find that both of these (and some underlying systems that improved them) were patched to reduce their effectiveness.
Which one was truly the intended way of playing the game? Was it before or after the developers changed it? What else will the developers change? Can developers change their intentions?
Some players that use this argument will make exceptions. For example, some enemies can be coerced into falling off of the map to their deaths, or get stuck such that they are easy targets. These will be exception cases, because their intuition tells them that the developers did not intend for enemies to simply fall off of the map and die on their own.
And yet, despite the developers being able to modify the game however they wish, patches keep going by where these supposedly unintended inclusions remain untouched.
When observing the design of the game, it is reasonable to try and guess developer intentions based on conflicting design principles and a charitable interpretation of the intelligence of whoever made it, even without the say of the developers. If in the vast majority of cases a condition is true, except for one specific case where there does not seem to be any reason for the deviation, an argument can be made that the aberration is not intended.
For example, in Elden Ring, there are almost always methods to avoid an instance of damage as a player of reasonable reaction time and positioning. Enemy attack patterns will place the attacks in such a way that that is always the case for their target. However, if there are multiple enemies, an attack may be placed in such a way that it is avoidable for the primary target, but not for any others nearby. This can be considered an unintentional side effect of the optional mechanic of multiplayer.
In Minecraft (Java Edition), players frequently modify the game using third party programs to drastically alter the gaming experience in ways far outside of the scope of the original game. It would be reasonable to assume that the intentions of the developer do not take into account anything a player may find in the landscape of unofficial changes to the game. Some of these modifications may be considered cheating, while most are considered changing the game entirely such that it is no longer "truly" Minecraft. However, there are modifications to the game whose only purpose is to improve the performance of the game, allowing more players the ability to play the game at all. Some modifications fix behaviors and perceived oversights to make the game more consistent.
Are these third party changes bringing the experience closer to what was intended? The Minecraft speed-running community certainly thinks that some do. Performance-boosting modifications that do not change the basic rules of the game are allowed and encouraged. It's intuitive that the game running better rather than worse is the intention of the developers. Being able to reset the game more quickly or load faster are generally accepted to not be considered in the realm of cheating due to not affecting the integrity of the performance of the player during their speed-run.
There it is—Integrity.

There is a sort of principled superiority that cheating is playing the game "wrong," and that accomplishments that were only acquired via cheating are illegitimate. This intuitive understanding is highly attractive, as speaking with someone who claims the same accomplishments as yourself while having a different experience reaching that goal will inevitably cause a disconnect. It can invoke feelings of mockery, as if your efforts are being undermined and cheapened by someone with a GameShark. Cheaters that are perceived to lack integrity are seen as dishonest and insincere.
It is no surprise that people will be on the lookout for any examples of something that can be seen as cheating. Whenever there are perceived rules and the perceived breaking of said rules, there will be conflict among players. Developers should keep this aspect of human nature in mind when designing their game, especially if they do not put any effort into explaining their intentions to the players.
Players are less inclined to fuss about cheating and accomplishments when difficulty and handicaps are properly communicated to them. When numeric and complexity difficulties are clearly labeled "Easy," "Medium," and "Hard" with descriptions of their effects, and opt-in mechanics are properly balanced or labeled as handicaps, players are more likely to be able to have civil discussions about the game's design.
At the end of the day, the purpose of games is to have fun. Players will act in accordance with what they find most enjoyable (and accessible), and they will associate with other players that have similar values to their own. Players are also not expected to have the emotional intelligence or logic capacity to put together well-reasoned and compassionate arguments to connect with others that do not think like them. They are expected to complain, pick sides, and attack anyone with opposing views, needlessly causing divides that the developers could have easily avoided.

Elden Ring is a gold mine of thoughtless arguments and assumptions from players due to the vague and often half-baked implementation of its core difficulty management mechanics. For this, we will be focusing on the debate around the users of summons against solo/difficulty purists, as both sides suffer from astounding levels of shortsightedness on the subject.
Let's start with solo purists that claim that anyone that used summons did not truly "beat the game" and that they "played the game wrong." There are legitimate arguments to be made about the poor implementation and incredible variance in effectiveness from the use of summons. Truly, they can be akin to using a Super Leaf in Mario games to skip entire areas and bosses from the sheer power that having another player or ally in a fight can bring. The way enemies do not take into account the presence of additional enemies for their choice of actions reveals a lack of polish or worse. In some cases, enemy AI will simply cease to function when a creature is defeated, or their movements and bodies will become unnatural as they change targets mid-attack, resulting in deceptive and jarring visuals that do not appear as intended behavior.
However, there is no reason to attack others for choices made for the purposes of entertainment in what may as well be a single-player game. Without the developers defining what it means to beat the game, like in Mario, the player's assertions are baseless.
As the player progresses further into the game, many of the enemies have identical gameplay with only minor cosmetic differences—and enormously increased statistics. It is not uncommon for a player to fight a generic soldier with a sword and trade hits to defeat them in one blow, only to find the exact same enemy wearing a different color shirt that can kill the player in a single blow. It is entirely possible for a player to simply not have enough ammunition to defeat even a single enemy from differences in numeric difficulty, resulting in certain playstyles being invalidated via arithmetic impossibility. What would normally be a method of difficulty control instead becomes a burden for the player to level up their character to unreasonable strength, skewing the experience unnecessarily because of arbitrary restrictions from the developers.
Furthermore, the action of increasing one's level has no relation to the core gameplay experience or player skill. If a player wishes to improve their numerical abilities until winning is possible, they will most likely resort to repeatedly resting at a save point and attacking defenseless enemies for an arbitrary amount of time until they have enough points to do so. There is no option to use skill to increase one's ability to deal damage when the resources used to do so are limited - if you have ten shots, and the enemy can survive eleven, no amount of skill will help you win. The increase in "difficulty" using numbers serves no purpose except to waste hours of a player's time when players opt for weaker strategies.
Strategies and weapons that are stronger or weaker are often touted as the game's main way of adjusting difficulty. In many cases, these are legitimate, non-invasive methods that do not significantly alter the core gameplay experience. If a player likes a specific kind of weapon or spell, chances are there are alternatives that function similarly enough while being substantially more or less effective. It's always easier to reduce effectiveness, as a player can choose not to upgrade a weapon, but it is not always possible to increase the strength of a playstyle past a certain point. That is the point at which this method of difficulty implementation fails.
It is a common argument among users of summons that anyone that complains about numeric difficulty while refusing to use opt-in playstyles is trapped in a cage of their own making. This view isn't just false, it's patronizing and misses the valid portion of the purist argument. Summoning, for example, changes the core experience of the game to such a degree that it can and will lead to questions of integrity and legitimacy in a run. Even inexperienced players identify that someone or something else defeating enemies for them "feels" like it made their own contributions irrelevant (because it did).
That all tools the game offers are equally valid means of managing difficulty is an equivocation. To insist others use them in the same way they would an "enemy health and damage multiplier" lacks nuance and borders on dishonesty. To the purists, telling them to "just summon" is no different than telling them to "just play Tetris instead," "just use the Super Leaf," or "have you considered handing the controller to your big brother?" since, to them, it is either an alternative game experience that doesn't interest them, or actively cheapens the experience of the game akin to cheating, even if the developers did not say such. To them, the game simply lacks the means to make their chosen way of playing the right difficulty, and their way of playing the game for entertainment is just as valid as the summoners.
This problem also exists in reverse. For example, what if someone wants to play with their friends, but does not want to make the game too easy? There are numeric ways to make yourself weaker, but the core experience is warped. No amount of self-restriction will make up for the fact that enemies in the game are not designed to act differently in the presence of multiple opponents.
There is one last drawback of opt-in mechanics as difficulty, especially in Elden Ring: Not all mechanics are even available from the start. If you want to play the game from start to finish with Godfrey's Axe, you are required to either arrange for another player to drop the item for you, or you need to cheat. That's right: there are playstyles that are not even accessible. The game does not have a reasonable method to enjoy items granted only after beating the game. This is not even for balance reasons either, as items like Fire Giant's braid and Godfrey's Axe are incredibly weak weapons compared to similar ones obtainable earlier in the game. Limited items exist that never respawn or force players to waste time collecting rare resources, which needlessly punishes inexperienced or challenge run players that are more likely to fail when using them.
Given everything discussed, using cheats for the purposes of enabling the game to be played in a specific way that does not affect the integrity of the core gameplay is something that should be reasonable to most. The issue is not cheating, it's integrity. There should always be methods of controlling difficulty within a given set of rules while respecting those rules, self-imposed or otherwise. If the developers fail to do so, it is perfectly within reason for players to point it out.

item.title: Math and Worldbuilding
item.description:
The Neglect of Mathematics and Game Balance in Tabletop Roleplaying Games

In all forms of interactive storytelling where numbers are involved, the narratives and imaginations of those involved are grounded in and informed by the underlying mathematics and mechanics. Just like in the real world, math is the basis on which everything exists - change one variable, and the world and the cultures within will look much different. Despite this foundational importance, the math in TTRPGs is often neglected or not taken into consideration during its creation, causing the stories built on it to lack plausibility or the players to engage in degenerate gameplay loops that are better incentivized by the math. We must elevate the standards of game balance and mathematical principles within to ensure a stable play environment with maximal freedom of storytelling.
For the purpose of this discussion, I'll mostly be referring to the design of Dungeons and Dragons, but these principles extend to all games, TTRPG or otherwise.


Here in the real world, our actions are most often decided by their expected outcomes. People grow the food that produces the most in the local terrain, they wear protection to avoid death, they take the path of least resistance, they outlaw actions that harm others. If the outcomes or goals were different, the actions taken would be different - if stabbing someone was a pleasant experience that extended their lifespan, then the laws around stabbing people would be very different. If we only ate for pleasure, we would grow what tasted the best regardless of climate. 
This is true down to the very foundations of the universe, where the actions that the atoms and forces of the universe take are decided by simple rules. Light takes the path of least time, mass and energy act towards increased entropy, and other such rules determine how everything else acts.
Just like in real life, expected outcomes are what guide us in TTRPGs. If the goal of the player is to live the longest and kill the most things, then the actions they take will be guided by what best gets them to that goal. Because this is based on probability, it becomes a question of simple math to determine the best course of action at a given moment. All else the same, the weapon that does the most damage should be what everybody in the world defaults to. All else the same, the strategy that prevents the most damage taken is the best. 
Math IS worldbuilding. 

In real life, we can't fight against monsters and men-at-arms with shuriken and our bare fists. Reality dictates that those actions would likely result in our demise. However, in a game, we often find ourselves roleplaying something that isn't exactly realistic - such as a magician slinging fireballs at ogres. If we want to allow the full range of themes to be represented in a game, we need all of them to be on a fair playing field. There is no purpose to allowing "Unarmed Strike" as an action that accomplishes nothing and gets you killed, after all - but we decide the rules of this universe. We can make "Unarmed Strike" deal substantial damage, or have additional benefits that make their use reasonable. By setting the rules properly, what is feasible changes to match our desires.
Whether what you desire is a good thing is a discussion for another day - let's focus on the hows.
What players do is a combination of what they desire, and what the game rewards. Developers should set the rules to reward what they want to happen, and not reward what they don't. Ideally, the incentives should match what the players want to do.

The incentive structure of a game like DnD usually comes in the form of power. More money and experience means bigger and more magical swords and fireballs, or more hirelings, etcetera. When you want a fair game for players to enjoy various themes and strategies, you must balance the power such that there is not a single overwhelmingly dominant strategy that is easily recognized by players. This is only fair; if you have multiple players, and one is given obviously inferior power, they may experience frustration or disengagement when they notice their impact on the game is insubstantial as a result.
Fairness in a system of mathematics is fundamentally a question of mathematics.
When the underlying math is neglected, and the rest of the game is built despite it, you will quickly find oddities. If you make "Unarmed Strike" deal 1 damage, and "Longsword" deal between 1 and 8, you should not be surprised when nobody will opt for "Unarmed Strike" under any circumstances. If there is a dominant strategy, and yet you still declare that most of the people in this world fight with fists instead of swords (all else equal), your world becomes less believable. From the math, the rest of the world-building should come naturally and without significant leaps of logic - If you declare something exists in this world, there should be a basis for it, and this basis almost always comes from the math.
Balanced systems inherently foster deeper engagement. Players are more likely to invest their time into the mechanics of a game when they believe they will not be held back by deviating from superior strategies. By employing mathematical approaches to skill scaling, damage output, resource allocation, and character progression, players are free to choose options based on thematics, creativity, and their own desires without worrying about doing the math on behalf of the developers to make sure they are being dealt a fair hand.
Everything I've stated so far may seem obvious, and even patronizing, but the reality is that most developers do not take this into consideration as much as they should.

I'll spare you the fine details and skip to the important math to keep in mind. 
In DnD, there are listed weapons that are assumed to be available from character creation. If we consider the world in which this takes place, it would be fair to assume that the people in the world would also want to survive encounters when selecting their weaponry, and those weapons are boiled down to sets of numbers and tags to describe them. The most important number to a commoner with no bonuses to anything is the damage number - in a fight, the odds to succeed are highest by simply using the weapon with the highest damage. And yet, a dagger deals 2.5 damage, while a stick deals 3.5. If they use a very big stick, they can even reach 4.5, if they don't mind using both hands. If they spend some more money and actions, they can use two axes for a whopping 7 damage, and this is only with "simple" weapons they may be proficient in.
The simple conclusion here is that, all else equal, a commoner's preferred weapon should be a stick, or two axes if they have money to spare. The stick is the most versatile, cheap, and powerful weapon available to them. Even if you take into account the bonuses from stats, a commoner would need maximum dexterity to consider a dagger, even compared to weapons they are not proficient in. In this world, using a dagger is mathematically inferior to every other option for any regular, non-player character. 
This results in a silly world that only suits the players, without taking into account the rest of the creatures. Why would a knife be a substantially worse weapon than a stick? 
A goat that attacks a human is likely to kill them in a single attack. How long would a farmer last in such a world?
Some classes and builds can easily survive far longer and deal multiple times as much damage as others, often while being better at non-combat activities as well. Why would anyone willingly choose to be the inferior class if the objective is to survive? 
The expected earnings of a player far outpace the earnings of commoners, as untrained labor is only enough to pay for a gallon of ale or a stay at a poor inn while a single piece of basic equipment can be worth a hundred times as much. Is it really acceptable to put the price on a day of deadly work (such as a mercenary) equal to the price of a dagger, one of the worst items in the game, such that a player could hire dozens of them for every adventure?
How long can you ride on a player's goodwill and desire for thematics and roleplay before these poor worldbuilding decisions start to interfere with their fantasy?

One of the most insidious phenomena in the world of TTRPGs is the tendency of players to defend poor mathematics and imbalanced mechanics, often born out of a fundamental misunderstanding or intentional ignorance of underlying principles. This defense frequently stems from a place of trust in the developers and an emotional attachment to the game itself, leading players to uphold the perceived authority of the creators.

"If they wanted it that way, they would have made it that way!"
"You think they didn't think of that? They clearly left it like that for a reason."
"Why don't you do better, then?"
When players encounter a system that is hailed as "official," there is a natural inclination to assume that the developers have meticulously crafted every detail, and thus, their choices are unquestionable. Players may erroneously believe that since the developers designed the game, they must have considered every possible variable and outcome, rendering any criticism unwarranted. 
Players may also propagate the myth of developer infallibility, asserting that they are privy to unique insights that justify design decisions. Such attitudes not only inhibit constructive discourse, but they also diminish the validity of collective player experiences and insights, as an entire community’s lived experiences may be rendered irrelevant in the face of perceived expertise. The belief that there "can’t be a better way" is a common claim that started among video game developers, such as at Riot Games and Nexon, as they frequently cite data they claim exists to justify their actions while refusing to release said data to prove it. The truth is that no such data exists, and modern gaming communities can easily get access to or create superior data from which to make decisions.
When confronted with suggestions for rebalance, players often leap to the defense of their cherished mechanics, positing that the developers "must have had a reason" for their choices. This blind and aggressive defense of the systems further perpetuates the cycle of flawed designs, as those advocating for improvement or merely offering their observations are dismissed as "Powergamers," or told that they're just not focusing on what matters, and that roleplay trumps game design.
Because the foundation of these defenses is inherently fallacious, they almost always lead to a statement that reveals their lack of engagement with the topic. The most common ones include that the game is made to be changed from table to table, that the suggestions are merely opinions and do not represent the needs of the community, that the opinions of those that are not part of successful gaming companies are inherently worthless, and basic attacks on the character of those criticizing the game (rather than focusing on the criticisms themselves).

Most players lack the mathematical literacy necessary to fully grasp the implications of game mechanics at a detailed level. Consequently, when flaws in balance emerge—be they overpowered abilities, inefficient resource distribution, or underwhelming options—players may misinterpret these issues as subjective preferences rather than objective mathematical failings. 
The most common misinterpretation of the math is that of percentage reductions: Most players do not know that reducing an effect by 100% is far more than twice as good as reducing it by 50%. A common way this ignorance appears is in video games such as League of Legends, Minecraft, and Skyrim, where players will honestly believe that combining a reduction of 50% with another 50% and getting a result of 75% is somehow a "diminished" effect because the total did not reach 100%, when in reality the result is a multiplicative, mathematically accurate, and fair way to represent the effect.
Combined with the aforementioned bias towards that which is "official," a majority of the population will convince themselves that their intuitive (incorrect) understanding of the underlying mathematics is also aligned with what the developers think - and, unfortunately, they may be correct.

The methods used by the developers of DnD to create the game and the underlying math is transparently dubious. By their own (unwitting) admission, the top-down approaches used by them with a lack of emphasis on mechanics and math, insufficient player testing, and dismissal of community feedback has led to books full of wondrous descriptions of a game that does not accurately match their vision in practice.
The examples of such are too numerous to list, but to bring up simultaneous examples that perfectly encapsulate the sheer nescience of the lead developers of DnD, we can look at the playtests of DnD 5.5. During the playtests, the developers made a particularly bizarre public video about the results, falsely claiming that a mechanic that players did not interact with was "mathematically one of the most powerful" when it was the worst on average, dismissing feedback because player scores on individual features were higher than the overall score, and even incorrectly referencing their own changes to their own content. 
What truly happened behind the scenes to cause such a public statement to be made without any proofreading is unclear. It's up to a given individual to review these actions to decide whether it's negligence, ignorance, or deliberate equivocation. I try taking the most charitable approach by assigning ignorance to what could have just as easily been malice.

Game developers must adopt a mathematical mindset in their approach. This includes rigorous playtesting with statistical analyses, iterative balancing, and a commitment to utilizing clear metrics for evaluating the effectiveness and fairness of mechanics while maintaining consistency and logic. Checking published content for faults should not be the burden of the players, especially when the product is advertised as being beginner-friendly. Disparities that can be encountered within a new player's first turn should not be tolerated, let alone upheld as intended design.
Players should be involved in the balancing process, and even perceived faults in criticism should be thoroughly investigated to identify the underlying reasons for the criticisms being put forth. When a community is particularly large, there's a high likelihood that there will be individuals that practically design the game in its entirety in their criticisms. To dismiss them is the peak of hubris. 
When a game's fundamentals and mathematical foundations are made airtight, the content built on them will likewise be untouchable. Under ideal circumstances, even inexperienced players should be able to expand on the content in the game with little worry of diminishing the balance. I hope to one day live in a world where criticisms of game balance and mathematics are truly in the realm of the nitpicking and biased, and that all game discussion becomes that of themes and abstractions.
